channel.title: philstar.com - RSS Headlines
channel.description: Philippine News for the Filipino Global Community

item.title: National Privacy Commission looking into public release of OFWs' COVID-19 test results
item.author: Kristine Joy Patag
item.description: Data privacy lawyer Cecille Soria pointed out that a negative COVID-19 test result of an individual is still health information and public disclosure of it is prohibited by guidelines of a government memorandum.

item.title: US chopper sale to Philippines would 'reward past abuses' — Human Rights Watch
item.author: Bella Perez-Rubio
item.description: Watchdog Human Rights Watch released a statement opposing the United States' sale of attack helicopters worth almost $2 billion to the Philippines.

item.title: Gamboa urges victims of sexual abuse by cops to file case against perpetrators
item.description: “I strongly urge those unnamed sources to immediately report to the PNP and to file charges against suspected wrongdoers,” Gamboa said.

item.title: Duterte accepts resignation of DICT's Rio
item.author: Bella Perez-Rubio
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte has accepted the resignation of Department of Information and Communications Technology Undersecretary Eliseo Rio Jr.

item.title: OCD deputy administrator sacked over 'loss of trust and confidence'
item.description: (Update 1, 10:26 a.m.) In a statement, presidential spokesperson Harry Roque said Purisima, who holds the rank of assistant secretary, has been “relieved from his post effective immediately due to loss of trust and confidence.”

item.title: SWS: Number of hungry Filipino families nearly doubles due to COVID-19 blow
item.description: The poll of 4,010 working-age Filipinos showed that 16.7%—which translates to around 4.2 million nationwide—experienced hunger due to lack of food to eat at least once in the past three months.

item.title: Barangays to continue assisting in cash aid
item.author: Alexis Romero
item.description: Even if President Duterte has tapped soldiers and police for fund distribution, barangay or village officials would still be involved in the giving of aid to sectors affected by quarantine restrictions, Malacañang said yesterday.

item.title: 500 OFWs test positive for COVID; 14,669 cleared
item.author: Robertzon Ramirez
item.description: More than 500 overseas Filipino workers have tested positive for coronavirus disease 2019 while 14,669 have been cleared of COVID-19 and are set to go home this month, an official said yesterday.

item.title: 1,152 quarantine violators arrested
item.author: Emmanuel Tupas
item.description: Up to 1,152 people were apprehended by police for breaching quarantine protocols, after President Duterte defended Metro Manila police chief Maj. Gen. Debold Sinas from criticisms he received for supposedly violating lockdown measures during his birthday gathering on May 8.

item.title: COVID displaces 400,000 arts, culture workers
item.author: Robertzon Ramirez
item.description: Some 400,000 workers in the country’s arts and culture sector have been left jobless as the government restricts mass gatherings amid the coronavirus disease 2019 pandemic.
